awd_titl_txt: Continuous Approaches to Optimization Problems in Graphs
awd_abstract_narration:
Discrete optimization problems arise in many important application areas, including computational biochemistry, social networks, telecommunications, and network-based analysis of big data. This award funds fundamental research to develop computationally efficient algorithms for solving hard discrete optimization problems using techniques from continuous optimization.  In addition to fundamental contributions to discrete optimization, the results from this research may stimulate new developments in continuous optimization.  The developed methodology will be integrated into the teaching curricula, as well as into research and educational programs at the undergraduate and graduate levels.

While convex relaxations based on linear, semidefinite, and conic programming represent a common feature of exact algorithms for discrete optimization problems, their non-convex counterparts have not been studied in this context, even though some of them can be solved efficiently. This research is to fill this gap by investigating non-convex relaxations of optimization problems that admit binary quadratic formulations (e.g., the maximum clique/independent set problems, minimum vertex cover, max-cut, etc.). This research will develop and analyze new continuous non-convex formulations of discrete problems; derive new optimality conditions for discrete optimization problems based on their continuous nonlinear formulations; deduct important computational complexity results for general and special cases of continuous optimization; obtain lower and upper bounds based on nonlinear formulations that can be utilized in designing exact branch-and-bound algorithms; and design approximation algorithms (with provable approximation ratio) based on non-convex, polynomial-time solvable relaxations.

por.por_cntn:
This project studies a class of cluster detection problems in complex networks from a new perspective. Given a network representation of a complex system, a typical cluster detection problem aims to find a maximum-cardinality subset of nodes inducing a sub-network with desired structural properties, e.g., easy reachability between the nodes within the group, high level of pairwise interactions between the group members, and resiliency of the corresponding sub-network to possible attacks.  

Many of such properties are known to be satisfied by a clique, which is a subset of nodes characterized by the presence of all possible pairwise connections between them in the network. In addition, several alternative models of a cluster have been proposed in the literature, aiming to overcome the drawbacks associated with the idealistic (and hence, excessively restrictive) nature of cliques.  These alternative models, often referred to as clique relaxations, tend to preserve some of the clique properties (in a relaxed form).  This project focused on investigating optimization problems dealing with finding cliques and clique relaxations in networks that maximize a certain objective, such as the total node or edge weight. These problems arise in numerous applications, such as biological and social networks, material science, energy systems, and network-based data analysis among others.

Due to their discrete nature, the problems of this type are traditionally approached using combinatorial optimization methods and integer programming-based algorithms. This project adds a novel avenue for attacking the problems of interest, based on their continuous non-convex formulations. Changing the vantage point provides a new perspective and leads to global optimization algorithms that improve upon the state of the art in solving some of the considered problems, such as the maximum edge weight clique problem. In addition, new network structures, such as maximum independent union of cliques, are introduced and studied, which may shed the light on some important questions in community detection, such as determining the appropriate number of clusters in unsupervised clustering.
